'''''Amanita echinocephala''''' is a large, whitish or ivory-coloured [[mushroom]] with a characteristic spiny, or warty-looking [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]]. It lives on chalky soils with [[beech]] trees, and appears earlier than most mushrooms of similar size in southern [[England]]. It frequently occurs singly or in small groups, resulting in it being referred to as the '''solitary amanita''' or, more specifically, '''European solitary lepidella'''. It is very drought-tolerant. ''Amanita solitaria'' is a [[Synonym (taxonomy)|synonym]] and opinions are divided as to which name takes precedence.
[[Image:Am.echin(2).jpg|right|thumb|Both of the images featured depict the same fruiting body. Note the pyramidal warts on the button.]]

==Taxonomy==
It was first described as ''Agaricus echinocephalus'' in 1835 by the Italian [[mycologist]] [[Carlo Vittadini]], before being placed in ''[[Amanita]]'' by [[Lucien Quélet]] and hence receiving its current [[Binomial nomenclature|binomial name]]. It derives its [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''echinocephala'' from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''echino-'' "hedgehog" and ''kephale'' "head".<ref name=Liddell1980>{{cite book | author = [[Henry George Liddell|Liddell, Henry George]] and [[Robert Scott (philologist)|Robert Scott]] | year = 1980 | title = [[A Greek-English Lexicon]] (Abridged Edition) | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | location = United Kingdom | isbn =0-19-910207-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Mushrooms & Toadstools in colour |last=Seymour |first=Jacqueline|year=1978 |publisher=Stafford Pemberton Publishing |location=Crows Nest, NSW |isbn=0-904681-43-2 |page=36 }}</ref> It has been placed in the ''Lepidella'' section of the Amanitaceae by some authors, because of its lack of a well formed volva. ''Amanita solitaria'' ([[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard|Bull.]]:[[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) Fr. is considered a synonym here but according to many modern authors (subject specialists in ''Amanita'', e.g., C. Bas or R.E. Tulloss) it is a valid name for this species.

==Description==
The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] can be up to {{convert|15|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} in diameter, and is white to ivory, or silver-grey in colour. It is covered in raised pyramidal warts, that become less well defined, and less frequent towards the margin. These are remnants of the [[universal veil]] which covers the mushroom in its earliest stages. The young buttons are darker, and sometimes shaped like a two tier loaf, with a ring of raised scales around the base. The white to ivory [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|8|–|16|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} high and {{convert|2|–|3|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} wide, with several rings of upturned scales towards the bulbous base. It is fairly deeply rooted, often laterally below the surface. The [[Annulus (mycology)|ring]] is thin and fragile, often adhering to the stipe. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are cream, but sometimes have a slight green tint.<ref name=C&D1995>{{cite book| author = Regis Courtecuisse and Bernard Duhem |edition=British | year =1995 | title = Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe | publisher = Harper Collins | isbn = 0-00-220025-2}}</ref> 
They are largely free of the stipe, but sometimes have a small decurrent tooth. The flesh is white, and is said to have an unpleasant smell.<ref name=Phillips06>{{cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006  | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6|page=151}}</ref>

===Similar species===
Because the two species often share the same growing ground, ''A. echinocephala'', and ''A. strobiliformis'' have both been erroneously identified as ''Amanita solitaria'' in the past.

*'''''[[Amanita strobiliformis]]''''' '''([[Carlo Vittadini|Vittad.]]) Bertill.'''  lives in the same locations, often at the same time. It is a more robust mushroom, with large thick; but flat patches on the cap, and typically has noticeable hanging veil remnants around the cap margin. With a delicate mealy ring.<ref name=Phillips06/>
* '''''[[Amanita vittadinii]]''''' '''(Moretti) Vittadini''' has conical warts on the cap, and has recurved scales right to the underside of the ring. It is usually found on heavier soils.<ref name=C&D1995/>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Amanita echinocephala'' occurs in Britain, Europe, [[Western Asia]], and [[North Africa]]. It appears in Britain during summer, and early autumn. It grows in light, dry [[calcareous]] soils with both broad leaved, (usually beech [[Beech|Fagus]]) and [[Pinophyta|coniferous trees]]. It is quite drought-tolerant, giving rise to the suspicion that Southern England could be at the northern extent of its range. It occurs with [[hardwood]]s on calcareous soils, often associated with Limes (''[[Tilia]]'') in the Czech Republic, sometimes together with ''A. strobiliformis''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Borovicka |first=J |year=2006|title=Notes on ''Amanita strobiliformis'' and related species of the section ''Lepidella''. |journal=Mykol. Sborn. |volume=83 |issue=2 |pages=43–46 |language=Czech}}</ref>

==Edibility==
Pronounced edible by some, but probably best avoided in case of confusion with other poisonous ''[[Amanita]]'' species. This mushroom is rare and protected. It is on the United Kingdom Red Data List. It was reported that this species [[bioaccumulation|hyperaccumulates]] silver.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Borovicka |first=J |year=2007|title=Hyperaccumulation of silver by ''Amanita strobiliformis'' and related species of the section ''Lepidella''. |journal=Mycol. Res. |volume=111 |issue=11 |pages=1339–1344 |doi=10.1016/j.mycres.2007.08.015 |pmid=18023163 |last2=Randa |first2=Z |last3=Jelínek |first3=E |last4=Kotrba |first4=P |last5=Dunn |first5=CE |display-authors=etal}}</ref> There are also reports about [[nephrotoxicity|nephrotoxic]] effects similar to [[Amanita smithiana]].<ref>http://ndt.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2011/09/29/ndt.gfr511.full</ref>
